Problem:

We examine the effect of a Fourier transformation \\( F(x) \\) defined by the function \\( F(x(t)) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty x(t)e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), on the system behavior.

If, at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), a transformation defined by \\( G(x) = \\int_{-\\infty}^\\infty x(t)e^{-\\lambda t} dt \\) (where \\( \\lambda \\) is a constant) is applied as an intervention, will the behavior of \\( x(T) \\) for T > t_1 solely depend on M?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( G(x) \\) introduces an additional transformation, which affects the displacement vector's trajectory by changing its decomposition and potentially introducing damping or other effects. This makes the endpoint \\( x(T) \\) dependent not only on M but also on the characteristics of \\( G(x) \\).
